text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of Gothic textura quadrata text with a full-width marginal miniature at foot, framed by red and blue borders. The image occupies the lower margin, separated from the text block by a ruled line. Visual hierarchy places the miniature apart from the body of text, serving as a pictorial vignette.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with decorative flourishes and extensive use of abbreviations

primary_colors: brown and grey for underdrawing and flesh tones
color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for the entire background to denote prestige. Red dominates the principal figures (clerics), symbolizing authority. Blue highlights (border and hat) create visual framing. Green used for secondary figure’s tunic. White highlights applied to drapery folds. Layered application evident in tunic folds, with subtle white brushing to model volume. Pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening of azurite.

features: Five figures arranged in a horizontal frieze
Architectural niche at left anchoring the seated figure
Gestural lines (finger pointing, raised hands) direct viewer’s eye
Hierarchical scale: seated woman slightly smaller to emphasize submission
Roofed canopy framing the leftmost figure

decorative_elements: Red border with white vine scroll
Blue border with white dot pattern
Architectural micro-frame: tiled roof and arch
Gold ground punctuated by incidental punchwork

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown ink with varied line weight emphasizing folds and facial features
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal shading, slight parallel hatching in drapery folds and cross-hatching in hair
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; overlapping figures suggest depth

content_theme.scene_description: A single investiture scene depicting five figures. At left, a fully armored soldier stands behind a seated woman within a small tiled niche. She wears a grey hood and robe, hands raised in greeting or acceptance. To her right three ecclesiastics approach: first, an elderly abbot in a vermilion robe and orange cap, gesturing with his right hand; next, an abbot or canon in a pink robe and blue hat, hand on chest; finally a bishop in green vestments bearing a gold crozier, partially framed by the red border. The figures overlap slightly to indicate spatial depth. The soldier’s mail and helmet, the woman’s monastic attire, and the clerics’ vestments are rendered with precise ink outlines and color washes. The architectural niche suggests an institutional setting, possibly an abbey or chapter house. Proportions emphasize the central cleric’s authority, while the seated woman is slightly reduced to indicate her subordinate role. A gold ground unifies the scene and elevates its ceremonial importance.

religious: Bishop in green vestments with gold crozier
Abbot in vermilion robe and orange cap
Cleric/Abbot in pink robe and blue hat
secular: Armored soldier with helmet and chain mail
Seated woman in grey monastic hood and robe

architectural: niche with tiled roof and arch

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth flesh side with faint hair-follicle pattern; regular quire structure with ruled text area
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments overall; minimal oxidation of azurite; gold leaf cracked but secure; minor flaking of red wash at fold; evidence of later stabilization along lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf visible at edge under UV
Underdrawing in brown ink detectable beneath color layers
Regular pricking and ruling for border and text alignment
Visible brush strokes in robe folds indicating layered application

functional_analysis.primary_function: Administrative (cartulary or book of statutes documenting abbey investitures)

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This marginal investiture scene likely originates from a mid-fourteenth-century convent cartulary produced in a French monastic workshop. The use of burnished gold leaf and high-quality pigments reflects institutional patronage and the importance of recording abbess appointments. The centralized composition and hierarchical scaling underscore the ceremonial transfer of authority, as the bishop and abbot flank the newly appointed superior. The schematic niche and soldier’s presence evoke an institutional setting, reinforcing the abbey’s autonomy and legal standing. Stylistically, the fluid pen work, restrained hatching, and polished color transitions align with the mature Gothic illumination tradition found in Parisian workshops influenced by the Chantilly Master. Technical features such as raised gesso and underdrawings demonstrate sophisticated material practices. Iconographically, the crozier and formal gestures map directly onto canonical investiture rites, embedding legal symbolism within a liturgical framework. Comparatively, the scene bears resemblance to investiture miniatures in the Chartres cartulary and the Cîteaux statutes, suggesting shared models or itinerant illuminators. This illumination thus embodies both local institutional identity and broader artistic currents of fourteenth-century monastic record-keeping.
